metadata.case_name: N. Krishna Iyer (for father Nilakanta Iyer) v. Official Receiver

facts.text: Koya Kunju died in or about 1921 leaving widow, two sons and two daughters who carried on ancestral business through eldest son under power of attorney. Added tile factory and oil mill.

In June-July 1924, sons approached appellant's father (Nilakanta Iyer), a money-lender at Mankompu, 50-60 miles from Quilon. He agreed to advance Rs. 75,000 on usufructuary mortgage of immovable properties after sons' enquiries.

Usufructuary mortgage Ex. I for Rs. 75,000 dated August 18, 1924 executed by heirs of Koya Kunju. Purpose: family necessity, carrying on trade. Properties unencumbered. Lease back same date at Rs. 6,750 annual rent equivalent to 9% interest.

Rs. 55,000 paid in cash on August 20, 1924 per receipt Ex. LIV. Remaining Rs. 20,000 in six instalments September 1-9, 1924 per receipts Exs. LVII, LVIII, LIX a, LXI a, LXIV a, LXV a. Supported by books Exs. LXVII-LXXII. Some paid to creditors.
Hypothecation bond August 30, 1924 for Rs. 78,859-15-0 to Kadir Moideen Rowther to liquidate debts from 1911 dealings. Hypothecated equity of redemption and other properties.

S. M. Sheikh Mohideen Rowther applied September 15, 1924 to adjudicate heirs as insolvents, alleging acts including mortgage and hypothecation to defeat creditors. Affidavit admitted debts ~2.5 lakhs, assets >7 lakhs.
District Judge adjudged insolvents August 29, 1927. Appointed Official Receiver interim receiver October 19, 1924.
Interim receiver report February 11, 1925: mortgaged properties yield Rs. 1,600/year, insolvents willing to pay Rs. 6,750 rent.
Rent arrears over two years; mortgagee sued for arrears, interest, possession, impleading Receiver. Decreed; mortgagee in possession since.

Official Receiver applied March 28, 1928 to annul transfers in Schedule A (usufructuary mortgage, lease, hypothecation) under ss.35,36 Insolvency Regulation. No specific fraud allegations for mortgage.
District Judge October 19, 1944: annulled mortgage; only Rs.20,000 paid, not bona fide; res judicata from adjudication.
High Court: full consideration paid, but not good faith (no due care); res judicata not applicable; appeal dismissed.
Mortgagee stranger to family; enquiries by sons via relation C.P.W.6; properties worth >1 lakh.
Insolvents owed Imperial Bank Rs.30,000-40,000; no dealings with Quilon Bank.

legal_issues.text: Whether the usufructuary mortgage Ex. I dated August 18, 1924 is within the third exception to s.35 of Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090 (Insolvency Regulation), i.e., made in good faith and for valuable consideration.
Whether burden of proof lies on Official Receiver or transferee to show lack of good faith and valuable consideration.
Whether adjudication order dated August 29, 1927 creates res judicata barring challenge to transaction's validity.
Appropriate test for 'good faith': due care and attention (Travancore General Clauses Act) or honesty (Indian General Clauses Act).

petitioner_arguments.text: Transaction bona fide for valuable consideration; full Rs.75,000 paid, evidenced by receipts, books, creditor witnesses.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.35 third exception, Travancore Insolvency Regulation; burden on Receiver per Privy Council cases

petitioner_arguments.text: Mortgagee stranger; made enquiries via sons and relation; no knowledge of insolvency.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Good faith means honesty, not due care

petitioner_arguments.text: No res judicata; misjoinder with hypothecation; limitation.

respondent_arguments.text: Transaction not in good faith; mortgagee failed due care/enquiry into financial position.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.35 Insolvency Regulation; good faith = due care per Travancore General Clauses Act s.2(6)

respondent_arguments.text: Only Rs.20,000 paid, not full consideration.
Res judicata from adjudication order alleging acts of insolvency including mortgage to defeat creditors.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee; s.35/36

court_reasoning.text: Burden on Official Receiver to prove lack of good faith/valuable consideration per Privy Council (Khoo Saw Cheow, Chettyar Firm, Pope).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below erred placing burden on transferee; prejudiced case.

court_reasoning.text: Full Rs.75,000 consideration paid; corroborated by receipts, books, creditors; late denial by insolvents rejected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Receiver failed to disprove; even if burden on transferee, proved.

court_reasoning.text: No res judicata; adjudication found acts by insolvents, not transferee's knowledge/bona fides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of transferee's good faith open.

court_reasoning.text: Good faith = honesty (Indian sense), not due care; insolvency protects honest creditors even if negligent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Travancore definition inapplicable due to repugnancy in context.

court_reasoning.text: Mortgagee honest; stranger, reasonable enquiries; no suspicion of insolvency; properties unencumbered, good reputation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence of privity to fraud.

holdings.text: Burden on Receiver under s.35 to prove transaction not in good faith/for valuable consideration.
Full consideration passed; transaction bona fide (honesty test); within s.35 third exception.
Good faith in insolvency = honest transaction, even if negligent; due care test inappropriate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Assignee v. Khoo Saw Cheow
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on assignee to prove lack of good faith/consideration under similar s.50.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Receiver v. P.L.K.M.R.M. Chettyar Firm
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed burden on receiver under Provincial Insolvency Act s.53.
Receiver must prove transferee knew of insolvency if real transaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahomed Siddique Yousuf v. Official Assignee of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata from adjudication under Presidency Act; not applicable here as no finding on transferee.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ex parte Learoyd In re Foulds
Official Assignee of Madras v. O.R.M.O.R.S. Firm

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Regulation VIII of 1090 (1915) (Insolvency Regulation)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfers void against receiver if insolvent within 2 years unless good faith/valuable consideration (third exception); annulment.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Regulation VIII of 1108 (1932)
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced 1915 Regulation; s.53 same as old s.35 except 'voidable'.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin Interpretation and General Clauses Act VII of 1125 (1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Good faith = without due care; inapplicable to insolvency.

statutes_cited.name: Indian General Clauses Act X of 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Good faith = honestly, even if negligent; appropriate for insolvency.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments below set aside; usufructuary mortgage and lease held binding on insolvents' estate; not annulled under s.35.

key_quotes.text: the onus is upon the Official Assignee to prove that a conveyance which he was seeking to set aside was not made in good faith and for valuable consideration.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes burden of proof on Receiver.

key_quotes.text: the test of honesty is more appropriate than the test of due care and attention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines good faith for insolvency proceedings.

key_quotes.text: Unless it is found that the transferee was wanting in bona fides in respect of the transaction in question, he cannot be affected by the dishonest course of conduct of the transferor.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Transferee protected if honest, regardless of transferor.
